name: Golden Spiny Mouse
description: It has a golden to rusty dorsal coat with stiff hairs typical of all spiny mice, and a whitish underbelly.
spread_note: Western Asia, Arabian Peninsula, and northeastern Egyptian desert
food_note: Mainly invertebrates, also seeds, fruits, and other plant parts
image_alt: Golden spiny mouse, photo: Pavel Brandl
proportions: Body length 4–13 cm; tail length 2–3 cm; weight 15–80 g
reproduction: Females are pregnant for 5–7 weeks. Young females give birth to 1–3 young, older ones typically have 3–5.
attractions: It lives in small groups without a fixed territory. A food source is crucial, which it uses very efficiently. Pups are born well-developed, capable of thermoregulation. All females in the group help care for the young. Spiny mice are active during the day, hiding in rock crevices when threatened.
breeding: We have kept them since 2003, when the first golden spiny mice arrived from Plzeň Zoo.
